sn30.2:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, phoenixes reproduce in these four ways.

sn30.2:1.4.eng: Phoenixes are born from eggs, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.

sn30.2:1.5.eng: These are the four ways that phoenixes reproduce.

sn30.2:1.6.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, aṇḍajā supaṇṇā aṇḍajeva nāge haranti, na jalābuje, na saṃsedaje, na opapātike.
sn30.2:1.6.eng: Of these, phoenixes born from an egg can only carry off dragons born from an egg, not those born from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.
sn30.2:1.6.comm: The enmity between snakes and birds is legendary (Ja 518), its origins related in the story of Suparṇa and Kadrū, mother of dragons (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.6.2). It is rooted as much in the common sight of birds attacking snakes as it is in the cosmic opposition between the solar and the chthonic, the forces of light in the sky and darkness beneath the earth. Only the Buddha could reconcile them (DN 20:11.16).

sn30.2:1.7.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, jalābujā supaṇṇā aṇḍaje ca jalābuje ca nāge haranti, na saṃsedaje, na opapātike.
sn30.2:1.7.eng: Phoenixes born from a womb can carry off dragons born from an egg or from a womb, but not those born from moisture or spontaneously.

sn30.2:1.8.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, saṃsedajā supaṇṇā aṇḍaje ca jalābuje ca saṃsedaje ca nāge haranti, na opapātike.
sn30.2:1.8.eng: Phoenixes born from moisture can carry off dragons born from an egg, from a womb, or from moisture, but not those born spontaneously.

sn30.2:1.9.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, opapātikā supaṇṇā aṇḍaje ca jalābuje ca saṃsedaje ca opapātike ca nāge haranti.
sn30.2:1.9.eng: Phoenixes born spontaneously can carry off dragons born from an egg, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.

sn30.2:1.10.eng: These are the four ways that phoenixes reproduce.”

sn30.3:1.2.pli: Aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn30.3:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn30.3:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti?
sn30.3:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the egg-born phoenixes?”

sn30.3:1.4.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena dvayakārī hoti, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī.
sn30.3:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does both kinds of deeds by body, speech, and mind.

sn30.3:1.6.eng: ‘The egg-born phoenixes are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn30.3:1.8.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
sn30.3:1.8.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the egg-born phoenixes!’

sn30.3:1.9.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
sn30.3:1.9.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the egg-born phoenixes.

sn30.3:1.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā aṇḍajānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
sn30.3:1.10.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the egg-born phoenixes.”

sn30.4-6:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn30.4-6:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn30.4-6:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā jalābujānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ …pe…
sn30.4-6:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the womb-born phoenixes …”

sn30.4-6:1.6.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena dvayakārī hoti, vācāya dvayakārī, manasā dvayakārī.
sn30.4-6:1.6.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does both kinds of deeds by body, speech, and mind.

sn30.4-6:1.8.eng: ‘The spontaneously-born phoenixes are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn30.4-6:1.10.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā opapātikānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
sn30.4-6:1.10.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the spontaneously-born phoenixes!’

sn30.4-6:1.11.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā opapātikānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
sn30.4-6:1.11.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the spontaneously-born phoenixes.

sn30.4-6:1.12.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā opapātikānaṃ supaṇṇānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
sn30.4-6:1.12.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the spontaneously-born phoenixes.”

sn30.7-16:0.3.eng: Ten Discourses On How Giving Helps to Become Egg-Born

sn30.7-16:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does both kinds of deeds by body, speech, and mind.

sn30.7-16:1.6.eng: ‘The egg-born phoenixes are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn31.1:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme …pe…
sn31.1:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery. …

sn31.1:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you about the gods of the centaur realm.
sn31.1:1.3.comm: The gandhabba (Sanskrit gandharva) is a complex mythic entity, but I think he sprang ultimately from the awe-inspiring sight of men on horseback, potent, unpredictable, violent, and sexy, from which came both the Greek kentauros and Sanskrit gandharva, “centaur”. See further discussions at SN 11.4:1.10, DN 20:9.3, DN 21, and MN 93:18.61.

sn31.1:1.5.eng: And what are the gods of the centaur realm?

sn31.1:1.6.eng: There are gods who live in fragrant roots,
sn31.1:1.6.comm: Here the centaur shows one of his many secondary characteristics, an association with fragrance (gandha), which arose as a pun on the word gandhabba. This serves to highlight his sensual and erotic nature.

sn31.1:1.16.eng: These are called the gods of the centaur realm.”

sn31.13-22:0.3.eng: Ten Discourses On How Giving Helps Rebirth in Fragrant Roots

sn31.13-22:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn31.13-22:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn31.13-22:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant roots?”

sn31.13-22:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does good things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn31.13-22:1.6.eng: ‘The gods who live in fragrant roots are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn31.13-22:1.8.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā mūlagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
sn31.13-22:1.8.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant roots!’

sn31.13-22:1.19.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā mūlagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
sn31.13-22:1.19.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant roots.

sn31.13-22:1.20.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā mūlagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
sn31.13-22:1.20.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant roots.”

sn31.2:1.6.eng: ‘The gods of the centaur realm are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn31.2:1.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā gandhabbakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
sn31.2:1.10.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of the centaur realm.”

sn31.23-112:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn31.23-112:1.12.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena sucaritaṃ carati, vācāya sucaritaṃ carati, manasā sucaritaṃ carati.
sn31.23-112:1.12.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does good things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn31.23-112:1.14.eng: ‘The gods who live in fragrant scents are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn31.23-112:1.16.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā gandhagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
sn31.23-112:1.16.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant scents!’

sn31.23-112:1.27.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā gandhagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
sn31.23-112:1.27.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant scents.

sn31.23-112:1.28.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā gandhagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
sn31.23-112:1.28.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods who live on fragrant scents.”

sn31.23-112:2.1.pli: (Evaṃ piṇḍakena ekasatañca dvādasa ca suttantā honti.)

sn31.23-112:3.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the centaur realm are completed.

sn31.3:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn31.3:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn31.3:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant roots?”

sn31.3:1.4.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena sucaritaṃ carati, vācāya sucaritaṃ carati, manasā sucaritaṃ carati.
sn31.3:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does good things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn31.3:1.6.eng: ‘The gods who live in fragrant roots are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn31.3:1.8.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā mūlagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
sn31.3:1.8.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant roots!’

sn31.3:1.9.eng: They give gifts of fragrant roots.

sn31.3:1.10.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā mūlagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
sn31.3:1.10.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant roots.

sn31.3:1.11.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods who live in fragrant roots.”

sn31.3:1.12.pli: yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā mūlagandhe adhivatthānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.

sn31.4-12:0.3.eng: Nine Discourses On Givers of Fragrant Heartwood, Etc.

sn31.4-12:1.14.eng: ‘The gods who live in fragrant heartwood … fragrant scents are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn31.4-12:1.35.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods who live on fragrant scents.”

sn32.1:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you about the gods of the thundercloud host.
sn32.1:1.2.comm: Valāhaka is not explained in any dictionary I have seen, and I have not been able to find it in pre-Buddhist texts. Trace to the root val (to “turn” or to “arc”). Appended with āha (“sky”) we have valāhaka, “one who arcs over the sky” like a constellation (cf. Sanskrit valana). This is the name of the horse of the universal monarch (MN 129:37.2), and metaphorically the “thunderclouds” that rumble like horse’s hooves. The link between horses and clouds recalls the Vedic Maruts, boisterous gods of the thunderclouds, who roamed about roaring in their chariot drawn by horses (Rig Veda 1.39.6, 1.87.4, 1.88.1, 5.42.15, etc.) or on horseback (RV 5.61.2), which are compared to the rainy clouds (RV 5.53.7, 8.7.28). Other deities also have horses associated with the thundercloud. The twin Asv́ins (“horsemen”) have horses that “thunder” (RV 5.73.7). The horses of Parjanya (Pali pajjuna) are “rain-bearing messengers” (RV 5.83.3). Bṛhaspati has horses “like a ruddy cloud” (RV 7.97.6). Pegasus, who was said by Hesiod to be the bringer of thunderbolts to Zeus, harks back to the same mytheme.

sn32.1:1.4.eng: And what are the gods of the thundercloud host?
sn32.1:1.4.comm: The “host” (kāya) is the four types.

sn32.1:1.5.eng: There are gods of the cool thunderclouds,

sn32.1:1.7.comm: Abbha (“stormy”) by itself just means “cloud”. In the Rig Veda they’re associated with wind (10.68.5), rain (10.77.1), and lighting (9.76.3), and in the Suttas they are described as “blue” (Thag 1.13:1.1).

sn32.1:1.10.eng: These are called gods of the thundercloud host.”

sn32.13-52:0.3.eng: How Giving Helps to Become a Warm Thundercloud God, Etc.

sn32.13-52:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn32.13-52:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn32.13-52:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā uṇhavalāhakānaṃ devānaṃ …pe…
sn32.13-52:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of warm thunderclouds …

sn32.13-52:1.7.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena sucaritaṃ carati, vācāya sucaritaṃ carati, manasā sucaritaṃ carati.
sn32.13-52:1.7.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does good things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn32.13-52:1.9.eng: ‘The gods of rainy thunderclouds are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn32.13-52:1.11.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā vassavalāhakānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
sn32.13-52:1.11.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of rainy thunderclouds!’

sn32.13-52:1.14.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā vassavalāhakānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
sn32.13-52:1.14.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of rainy thunderclouds.

sn32.13-52:1.15.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā vassavalāhakānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
sn32.13-52:1.15.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of rainy thunderclouds.”

sn32.2:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn32.2:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn32.2:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā valāhakakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti?
sn32.2:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of the thundercloud host?”

sn32.2:1.4.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena sucaritaṃ carati, vācāya sucaritaṃ carati, manasā sucaritaṃ carati.
sn32.2:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does good things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn32.2:1.6.eng: ‘The gods of the thundercloud host are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn32.2:1.8.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā valāhakakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
sn32.2:1.8.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of the thundercloud host!’

sn32.2:1.9.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā valāhakakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
sn32.2:1.9.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the thundercloud host.

sn32.2:1.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā valāhakakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
sn32.2:1.10.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of the thundercloud host.”

sn32.3-12:0.3.eng: Ten Discourses On How Giving Helps to Become a Cool Thundercloud God

sn32.3-12:1.1.comm: The numbering in the PTS editions goes awry here.

sn32.3-12:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn32.3-12:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn32.3-12:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sītavalāhakānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti?
sn32.3-12:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of cool thunderclouds?”

sn32.3-12:1.4.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, ekacco kāyena sucaritaṃ carati, vācāya sucaritaṃ carati, manasā sucaritaṃ carati.
sn32.3-12:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, it’s when someone does good things by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn32.3-12:1.6.eng: ‘The gods of cool thunderclouds are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

sn32.3-12:1.8.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sītavalāhakānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
sn32.3-12:1.8.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of the cool thunderclouds!’

sn32.3-12:1.11.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sītavalāhakānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
sn32.3-12:1.11.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of cool thunderclouds.

sn32.3-12:1.12.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yena midhekacco kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sītavalāhakānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti.
sn32.3-12:1.12.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of cool thunderclouds.”

sn32.53:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn32.53:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, that mendicant said to the Buddha:

sn32.53:1.3.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yenekadā sītaṃ hotī”ti?
sn32.53:1.3.eng: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why sometimes it becomes cool?”

sn32.53:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, there are what are called gods of the cool thunderclouds.

sn32.53:1.6.pli: ‘yannūna mayaṃ sakāya ratiyā vaseyyāmā’ti, tesaṃ taṃ cetopaṇidhimanvāya sītaṃ hoti.
sn32.53:1.6.eng: ‘Why don’t we revel in our own kind of enjoyment?’ Then, in accordance with their wish, it becomes cool.

sn32.53:1.7.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, ayaṃ paccayo, yenekadā sītaṃ hotī”ti.
sn32.53:1.7.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why sometimes it becomes cool.”
